headline: Citrus Turkey Brine
description: This easy citrus turkey brine adds fresh, bright flavor to your holiday bird and ensures juicy, tender meat — no matter how you decide to cook it.
name: Citrus Turkey Brine
recipeIngredient: 1 (12 pound) fresh, whole, bone-in skin-on turkey, rinsed and patted dry

recipeInstructions.text: Rub turkey all over with salt. Place remaining salt into a large stainless steel or enameled stockpot.
Add onion, orange, and lemon wedges to the pot, along with garlic, bay leaves, thyme, and pepper. Place turkey into the pot and pour in cold water. Cover and refrigerate, 8 hours to overnight.

When ready to cook, discard brine. Rinse turkey, then pat dry and place in a roasting pan. Refrigerate, uncovered, for 2 to 3 hours. Roast, grill, or deep-fry turkey according to your favorite recipe.

Typically I add more of what it calls for but keep the salt to the ratio to water. Every year with my big family of 20 or more we get nothing but complaints on the flavor and mistress. Best turkey I've ever made was with this brine! I followed the suggestion to cook the ingredients on the stove first, to dissolve the salt and allow flavors to steep (mostly because I hate touching raw poultry). Easy, and the flavor was excellent.

Use sea salt or Himalayan or other good salt for a nice subtle and more flavorful brine that lets the citrus shine through. I also thought more citrus was needed and ended up adding a can of orange juice concentrate to be able to even taste the citrus.

The only modification I made, other than upping the brine to accommodate the larger bird, was to add 1/2 cup of brown sugar to the mix. Other than that, it was done as written.

I used a 5-gallon bucket and brined a small turkey, then rotisserie-cooked it on the grill. It turned out super moist, with a kind of smokey flavor, and really tasty! Each bird was very moist, juicy, and "0h so flavorful!"
My dinner guests were trying to name "each" spice they tasted. All positive remarks. My male guests (all self-proclaimed chefs) were comparing my birds to their best "previous " feats of clamor.
Today I received a few positive comments from dinner guests about how good the turkeys were. This brine works!

I made this brine for our 2015 Christmas Turkey and let it do it's magic for 2 days in the fridge. My family said it was the best tasting Turkey they ever had! This brine is a keeper. Thanks for sharing!

We have used this recipe for years and it produces a marvelous turkey. I have spent kagillions of dollars on fresh birds and now can make a utility bird taste just as good with the brine. 24 lb bird + 2 lemons 2 limes 2 oranges 1 onion 6 cloves of garlic sliced peppercorns brown sugar fresh thyme rosemary and oregano and a 8 oz container of frozen orange juice and 1 cup kosher salt - iodized salt is too salty.. I make the brine the day before and simmer for 1 hour then cool till it is cool. Do not place the turkey in a warm brind. Place bird and brine in a large bucket adding water if necessary to cover entire bird and let sit for minimum 24 hours. Keep in a cool place, sometimes there isn't room in my refrigerator so I keep it on the cold garage floor. I add a tray of ice cubes every few hours to make sure it stays cold. Rinse bird really well. Those who say it's too salty don't rinse the bird enough. Enjoy and thanks for posting this recipe it's a holiday tradition in our house!

I have always used Alton Brown's Salt Brine recipe and thought I would try this one. I really liked the moistness and flavor. I used a 5 gallon bucket from the hardware store that was doubled lined with two garbage bags. I used the recipe rather closely but added sliced candied ginger. For the liquid I used 8 cups of water and 2 quarts of orange juice. Then to make sure the entire bird was cover, I topped it off with water. The turkey brined for almost 24 hours then I removed the liquid, wrapped up the bird in the garbage bag and store it in the refrigerator for 12 hours. To roast I added to the cavity, two quartered small oranges, a quartered lemon, fresh parsley and thyme. It was delicious!

taking the base recpie and what others suggested i made a version i really loved. cut the salt in half and replace with brown sugar in the water. i did a 2 to 1 ratio of oranges to lemons, make sure you zest them and put the zest in the water! the rest is the same but i did also make a sage and thyme infused butter and put it under the turkey breast skin and it brought it all togeather!

If you follow this recipe and the perfect turkey recipe this Thanksgiving/Christmas, your nieces and nephews will ask "Are you making the turkey next year?" Great brine.
I have used this recipe for three years now. It's easy and the turkey is super moist. Everyone always love's my turkey. Thanks for sharing the recipe!! It's a good one.

I always dissolve the kosher salt and brown sugar in boiling water, while the water's hot, add the fruit, bay leaves, whole black pepper, fresh thyme and sage. Then I add ice to the mixture. I keep an ice chest that is only used for brining and use disinfectant ( white vinegar usually) to clean it out. Add 10 pounds of ice, add the warm/hot brine mixture, add Turkey, add more ice/water as needed to make sure the Turkey is covered. Place something heavy over the top of the Turkey to keep it submerged. Add ice as needed. I normally brine for at least one day but sometimes two. SO good.

I always get rave reviews on my Turkey when I use this brine!!! Because I have an extremely large turkey, I double the recipe. Instead of adding all the water, I add some orange, lime and cranberry juice. Like I said.....RAVE reviews!!!

This is my favorite brine! I do add 1/2c. brown sugar and boil the ingredients with about 1/3 of the water. After the water cools completely add the rest of the water--sometimes I even add orange juice-then add the turkey to the brine. I do rinse and dry the turkey before baking.

Just took this bad boy out of the oven and carved it! So super good! Never tried to brine a turkey before and this was wonderful!

Used this two years ago and everyone raved. Going to do it again this year because I have more people and no time to try something I don't trust! It was a lot easier than I thought brining would be, and so juicy!

I was so disappointed when I realized I had purchased a Butterball turkey, which has basting added to it and so you can't brine it or it ends up too salty. So, having a bright idea, I called the folks at Butterball and they confirmed my idea. If you want to brine your turkey, and find the one you purchased already has added basting to it, simply don't add salt to your brine. So, my brine will consist of apples and juice, oranges and juice, lemons and juice, vegetable broth, garlic, rosemary, thyme, sage, summer savory and onions. NO SALT. They said at Butterball that I could still brine my turkey as long as I cut down on the salt I used in it. I will also, when I roast the bird, stuff it with apples, oranges, lemans, celery, garlic and the herbs inside the cavity as well as a butter of butter, savory, sage, thyme, garlic and Rosemary put under the skin. I will let everyone know how it turns out.
LOVE THIS i DO IT EVERY YEAR REALLY KEEPS THE TURKEY JUCICY
My whole family loves this recipe. We've used it for chicken, turkey & Cornish game hens. We've also added sage & juniper berries for variety. I definitely recommend it.
Very delicious. Makes for a juicy turkey. I've used this for years and it works wonderfully.

This is amazing! I use this for my chicken and my turkey. I stuff my poultry with the same ingredients used in the brine and then bake it for the recommended time. The meat is always tender and flavorful.And the gravy from the drippings is to die for!
I followed the recipe exactly as written and used the (Rosemary roasted Turkey) recipe from this site. It was the best turkey i ever had!

Used this reciepe this Thanksgiving. Got rave reviews from the family. I cut the salt in half and added a half cup brown sugar, and doubled the whole thing for my 22 lb. turkey and let it soak in a 5 gal. bucket. It was wonderful.

I followed this recipe to the T. The turkey was so moist and delicious. I hardly had any left overs! Anyone complaining that it was to salty must not have rinsed the bird after it was removed from the brine. As many have already stated, you must rinse, pat dry and bring the bird to room temperature before you baking.

I've used this brine for years at Thanksgiving and it has always resulted in rave reviews by our family and guests. I think a huge part of that success is that I drain the turkey from the brine and stuff with new wedges of oranges, lemons, onions and add celery. I grill our turkey on a gas grill (turkey is placed in a conventional roasting pan with a rack/cooking grate) at 350 degrees and amazingly I don't have to baste but once and this turkey cooks far faster than an oven. For those who feel the recipe doesn't work - don't use a frozen turkey, always use fresh ingredients (including thyme), and keep it refrigerated, not cool, but cold. I have looked for alternative recipes and this one just beats them all.
I made this last year and loved it! This year I doubled the recipe for a 18lb turkey.

This was the first time I have ever had a brined turkey and I have to say the juice just poured out of it like never before. I do not particularly like turkey, but I always cook a 20 to 24 pound bird for Thanksgiving. I did not rub salt on the bird first, but put all of the dry ingredients in a sauce pan with about one quart of water. I dissolved the salt in the water over medium heat. I then transferred the mixture to a large stainless bowl, added ice, water, the sliced fruit, onion, and garlic. I put my turkey in two Reynolds oven bags (I doubled them to prevent leaking). Then I placed the turkey in a large party ice bucket, poured the cold brine into the bags, removed the air and double tied it before putting it in my fridge for 36 hours. Thanksgiving morning I took the bird out three hours before it was to go into the oven, rinsed it thoroughly, dried, and stuffed with dressing. The turkey roasted for five hours and I let it rest for 30 minutes before carving. I did not baste the turkey at all and the pan drippings yielded one quart with the fat removed. I made my gravy from the pan drippings and neck meat. The most important thing about the gravy – do NOT season before tasting it. Mine had the maximum amount of salt in it to still be OK. If I had added salt to the gravy, it might have been inedible due to the salt coming out of the turkey from the brining. I found the meat to be flavorful and moist, and not salty tasting since I used an unbasted store bought turkey.

This recipe was received with great reviews from everyone at the table. I was so impressed! brined my bird for 36 hours before putting it in the oven and man!! was it succulent and moist. I'll make again. Thank you so much!

WOW.!!!! I will never make a turkey any other way. Followed recipe exactly and did not change or add a thing. Cooked turkey breast side down after and it turned out amazing, moist, flavorful , and delicious.!!!!

I used this all the time to marinade a whole chicken, it would work well with chicken parts, too. I use lemon juice when I don't have lemons and I have subbed orange juice when I don't have oranges, which is often.

I frequently use this brine. It's perfect for Beer Butt Chicken. Everyone raves about the juiciness and flavor. I add black peppercorns and bring to a boil to dissolve the salt and get the flavors going. I'm thinking of throwing in a few dried hot chilies next time.!

I have used this same general recipe on a Capon and followed up with the classic forty cloved of garlic James Beard was so famous for contriving. I took it to the lake with family and I had to leave for a few hours and when I returned they had eaten it like wolves! They "saved" me the bony pieces! They couldn't quit eating it!Needless to say, this is a winning way to prepare poultry.

Great, great, great! This brine recipe makes for a succulent, juicy bird. I did heat the brine to boiling, then cooled before placing the bird in the brine. I also liked one reviewer's suggestion to put some citrus juice into the brine, which I did in my second time using the recipe. I also recommended this recipe to my son's father-in-law for a Christmas dinner we were invited to. Super flavor! Funny how you are able to enjoy more a meal you don't cook.
I have been using this brine recipe for years and it never fails.
This is my go to brine! Sooooo good!!! I've used it with Cornish Game Hens as well, but only for 2 hours! Yum!
Have used this recipe several times now and find that the brine helps with the final defrosting of the turkey and to improve the flavour and texture of the cooked bird.

Used this brine for a 6lb. turkey breast so I should have cut the salt back somewhat but overall the brine was great! As a side note: To cook, I "buttered" the breast with bacon grease and basted it with (no pun intended!) Wild Turkey bourbon!
Great flavor, turkey stayed moist.

I made this recipe last Thanksgiving for my my husband who is not a big fan of turkey. He loved it! I'm making it again this year.

This the the juiciest turkey you will ever eat. I give it a BIG 10!!

I increased the salt, which I think may have been a mistake. I would stick to the recipe on that one if I were you.
I brought all the ingredients to a boil with some water in a pot first and then let cool before I added to the turkey in a larger bucket with some more water. This helps to bring out the flavors.
I also added a little rice vinegar and used whole peppercorns instead of ground pepper. Good recipe for a springtime bird! Brining is a MUST.

I'm not sold on this. I changed the servings to 5 for a chicken. It didn't taste citrus-y at all. The chicken legs also turned out very salty. However, the chicken breast turned out very well, and not even dry after re-heating twice. I think I'll still stick with other brines, but this wasn't bad.
PERFECTO! Made a few modifications, just added additional citrud, more than what it called for. Everyone in my family LOVED it, huge turkey with NO leftovers :)

Dark meat tasted spectacular. Breast seemed a bit odd on first taste, but as leftovers the breast was so moist and delicious. The only real complaint was that the skin didn't crisp up very nicely. Too moist maybe? We made this in the Weber barbecue as we always do. I wasn't sure at first if I would do this again, but after tasting the leftovers that were in the freezer for 1-1/2 months, I'm sold. Best Thanksgiving leftovers ever.
Love it! I have used this brine the last two Thanksgivings and I've never considered going back to any other way to cook my turkey!
We did this for Thanksgiving and the Turley was amazing!!!
I pretty much created my own recipe & used the citrus from this one...OMG! Citrus gave my turkey an amazing flavor! It was sooo good & hubby loved it! Will totally use again. Thx for sharing.

I had to omit the onion and garlic due to allergies in the family, otherwise followed the directions. I did brine for a full 24 hours as I had a 20 lb turkey. It was still very moist. I used butter and herbs under the skin, basted with oj, cooked breast side down for about 3/4 of the time then turned over, and it came out very good, very moist and tender. really went pretty quick, not a lot of leftovers.

I used this recipe last year and my family loved it! I did deviate slightly from the recipe. Along with the wedges of fruit in the brine, I also stuffed wedges in the cavity. I rubbed olive oil on the skin and sprinkled with some kosher salt. Everyone agreed that this was the best turkey ever! The meat was so moist and flavorful! Absolutely wonderful!
Brined the T-day turkey in this for 24hrs this year. Smoked the turkey for 6hrs and cooked for 3hours more. Most moist turkey ever. Good sweet flavor.
